posts.cooked: Do teams design the superstructures first or determine the frame size first? How is the frame perimeter of a robot generally decided?

posts.name: Rocky
posts.cooked: My team did like “Oh, last year’s bot was 26x26, let’s make this year 28x28”, and we fastly determined this year’s frame perimeter

posts.name: Chad (Team5046)
posts.cooked: We generally determine by drivetrain.  When we used to use mechanum or now swerve it’s square. For tank it’s almost always the long orientation. Except for recycle rush where wide made sense.  Then we go for the maximum frame perimeter and subtract 1-2 inches total  to account for inspector tape measure errors.

posts.name: Jeremiah Johnson
posts.cooked: We determined our frame perimeter after deciding what sort of subsystems we were going to focus on - minus about 2 inches in perimeter for a flub factor. However, at our first competition we figured out that we were too long to actually set up in front directly in front of the speaker so in hindsight we should have gone the other way.

posts.name: Christopher149
posts.cooked:
We want it narrow enough to fit through standard doors with bumpers on, which effectively limits it to around 27 inches in one direction.

Also we transport it and the pit contents in a minivan, and between this year and last year the effective limit with our current layout seems to be a total robot size of a bout 27x27x40 inches. Last year’s was that 27x27x40, this year’s is 27.25x30.25x26-ish and we tip it on one end for transport. The 30 dimension this year just looked about right in CAD.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor

posts.name: Liu
posts.cooked: I think with the corner swerve modules, they allow for frame sizes to be fluid through the design phase. I think the best course of action is to design the internals of the robot and then size your frame around it based on your criteria, so small if you want to be fast and nimble, or large if you want to push teams away or play defense.

posts.name: Peter Matteson
posts.cooked:
Determine the frame perimeter first by figuring out if there is a specific need to fit in a space for game reasons, like 3 robots on the ramp last year.  Based on that set the base frame size and work from there to make sure you are under the limit.

No need to go to the full frame perimeter unless there is a specific design related need.  Always plan to give yourself .25-.5 inches leeway on any side of the robot because tolerances and late adds will always get you if you build to the exact limit.

posts.name: Sean Lavery
posts.cooked:
Peter_Matteson:

No need to go to the full frame perimeter unless there is a specific design related need. Always plan to give yourself .25-.5 inches leeway on any side of the robot because tolerances and late adds will always get you if you build to the exact limit.

Totally agree with leaving yourself some wiggle room (in the age of 0.5" pre-drilled frame rails, easy to go 0.5" under in each dimension).

But I think that, unless there’s a specific game task that benefits a smaller frame (the triple balances in 2023 and 2012 being two big examples), going significantly undersized is a trap for 80-90% of teams. If there’s not an explicit strategic advantage that will make you a more attractive pick in alliance selection for being smaller, I think generally building closer to the max size is the right pick for the bulk of teams out there. It means there’s more more inherent frame mass down low, and more space to allocate other mass to be low. It means there’s a lot less packaging headaches as the robot is designed. It means there’s more space to get hands and tools in place for maintenance.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: “Go through the school doors” is critical Bonus points if it will go WITH the bumpers on!

We’ve been taking the ‘make it as square and as small as possible in CAD, then build it to see if it works’ the past 2 years and probably will going forward. There are so many benefits offensively these days to being small and short, and we’ll probably only go bigger if a larger drive base is required for stability.

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked:
It really is all about the whole robot design.  You need to account for the size of the game piece and the size of your mechanism to manipulate it.  Last year, that meant length was a critical aspect, as our mechanism to extend to place on the upper row was limited by the length we had available inside the robot.  This year, with a fairly wide game piece and a desire to intake inside the robot, ensure the wheels were placed far enough apart was critical.  All of that serves to help you generate minimum requirements for one or more dimensions.

Then you have external game play factors that may push down the size of your robot.  Limited space for game actions, like trying to fit multiple teams on the chain, argue for a smaller robot.  Cycling paths may argue for a smaller robot, if there are bottlenecks to worry about - this year, the stage argued for a lower height robot, for example.  So all of that can help you determine maximum requirements for one or more dimensions.

After that, it comes down to looking at how you can manage your center of gravity and avoid tipping over.  for that, shorter robots with a larger footprint (focusing first on going square, especially with swerve drive) is a huge plus.
